content: malabrigo hat by susan ashcroft yarn any weight from fingering to aran see page 2 for cast-on numbers and details allow approx 150 - 250m/175 - 275yds in total depending on how slouchy you want it suggested needle size and gauge see table size approx 55cm/22 knitting in the round use your favourite technique for the crown - 2 circulars magic loop or double-pointed needles supplies one stitch marker malabrigo arroyo on 4 5 mm/us 7 abbreviations k = knit p = purl st s = stitch es k2tog = knit 2 sts together p2tog = purl 2 sts together you can find more yarn ideas and projects linked to the pattern page on ravelry - link xstitch malabrigo rios on 5mm/us 8 © ashcroft-hempsall 2018 - for personal non-commercial use only malabrigo hat 2 making the hat i have suggested the likely needle size if you have average gauge the main thing is the gauge if you knit tighter your hat will be smaller looser gauge will make a bigger hat to swatch rs row 1 k1/p1 ws purl all sts row 3 p1/k1 if you wish to adjust you can use any multiple of 8 stitches weight probable gauge per 4 /10cm cast on number of needle size repeats fingering 4mm 20 sts 104 sts 13 sport 4 5mm 18 sts 96 sts 12 dk 4 5mm 16 sts 88 sts 11 worsted 5mm 14 5 sts 80 10 aran 6mm 72 9 link for cable cast-on http //stitchnerd blogspot be/2011/10/cable-cast-on html tips tip 1 take care not to twist your stitches when joining - check again when you start round 2 because if you do have a twist you can still untwist then tip 2 try on your hat after a few rounds to check the fit main section work from the chart on the next page or written instructions below start by working round 1 and then placing marker and joining to work in the round repeat rounds 1-4 until you are ready to start the crown round 1 p1/k1 to the end of the round rounds 2 + 4 knit all sts round 3 k1/p1 to the end of the round the crown is quite shallow so the hat should be nearly the desired length before you start to work it work the crown from the chart rounds 5 16 or written instructions on next page finishing your final number of stitches will be the same as the number of repeats pull the yarn end through to secure block lightly © ashcroft-hempsall 2018 -
